etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Hall's Vnion. From scritch

definitions: A loud shrill cry or screech.

notes.text: Largely superseded by screech by the beginning of the 20th century; later use is chiefly regional (especially in the south-west of England) or poetic.

etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in The Owl and the Nightingale. Imitative

definitions: To utter a loud shrill cry or screech.

notes.text: Largely superseded by screech by the beginning of the 20th century; later use is chiefly regional (especially in the south-west of England) or poetic.

etymologies: 1920s; earliest use found in The Charleston Gazette. Probably a variant or alteration of scratch, probably after scritch and perhaps also partly after itch

definitions: To scratch; (now) especially to scratch (a pet) affectionately with one's fingernails.
To make a scratching sound; especially (of an animal's claws) to scratch noisily on or across a surface.

etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Harper's Young People. Probably a variant of scratch, perhaps arising from vowel alternation in a reduplicated form, or perhaps immediately after scritchy

definitions: Representing a scratching or scraping sound.
